markdownRemark.html:
Short and sweet. A quick read that goes straight to the point. A **4-star** rating on [my GoodReads](https://www.goodreads.com/user/show/3186522-j-pedro-ribeiro).

Here are my highlights:

  1. (…) they are made up of a soft fleshy exterior with a shell that hosts the seed that we know as the coffee bean. (pg.21)
  2. Your nervous system receptors are constantly monitoring your level of adenosine, and when they get too high, your brain will slow down your neural activity and dilate the blood vessels, making you feel sleepy or crave rest. Caffeine has a similar molecular structure to adenosine (…) meaning it can bind to your nervous system’s adenosine receptors without activating them.(pg.33)
  3. Once consumed, caffeine is absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract and can remain in your system for between 6 and 8 hours. (pg.34)
  4. Because it is both fat and water soluble, caffeine passes easily through the blood-brain barrier. (pg.34)
  5. (on Pulsing method)… you take breaks at certain intervals to allow the water to drain… one break every 50/60 grams. (pg.41)
  6. (on Blooming)… when you wet coffee grounds, they swell and bubble as the carbon dioxide is released. (pg.42)
  7. (Stick to bleached paper)… as natural filters tend to give coffee a papery taste. (pg.53)
  8. Overextracted coffee - the kind that has spent too much time with hot water - tends to taste bitter. (pg.61)
  9. When you use a blade grinder, some coffee beans get pulverized while others remain coarse. (pg.86)
  10. Oxidation happens when oxygen molecules from either the air or the water in the coffee mingle with other molecules to create entirely different compounds that taste different from the original ones. Hence, stale coffee. (pg.104)
  11. Almost all instant coffee is robusta. (pg.108)
  12. Brazil is the biggest coffee producer in the world. (pg.131)
  13. All green coffee beans are kind of boring - they don’t smell or taste like much. (pg.144)
  14. Some people like the terroir of the plant associated with wine. Other people like the aging/barreling process associated with whiskey. (pg.148)
  15. Higher-quality beans are grown at higher elevations. (pg.168)
  16. Cold coffee beans break apart in the grinder more consistently. (pg.182)
  17. Coffee too acidic (sour), likely means your brew is underextracted. (pq.252)
